title: Media watch groups ranks Mexico as the second most dangerous country for journalists to work
text:
At least five journalists have been murdered in Mexico this year, and at least 30 deaths have gone unsolved in the past decade, making the country the second most dangerous for the working media in the globe, according to a new report.

Figures released Tuesday by the Committee to Protect Journalists confirmed that five Mexican journalists since January have been killed carrying out their job. The deaths of a further six journalists have gone unconfirmed in Mexico this year.

In total, 81 journalists and one media worker have been assassinated in Mexico dating back to 2009.

Nevith Condes Jaramillo, who ran local news website El Observador del Sur, was stabbed dead August 24 in Tejupilco, a city in the State of Mexico.

Jorge Celestino Ruíz Vázquez, a reporter for the newspaper El Gráfico, was shot dead August 2 at a store he owned in the eastern state of Veracruz.

Mexican authorities have yet to solve either murder.

The country with the largest number of unsolved killings was the Philippines with 41, followed by Mexico, the group said.

Nevith Condes Jaramillo, who ran local news website El Observador del Sur, was stabbed dead August 24 in Tejupilco, a city in the State of Mexico. His death is one of at least 30 that have gone unsolved in Mexico since 2009

Jorge Celestino Ruíz Vázquez, a reporter for the newspaper El Gráfico, was shot dead August 2 at a store he owned in the eastern state of Veracruz. At least 81 journalists and one media worker have been assassinated in Mexico since 2009

Overall, more than 200 killings of journalists have gone unsolved in 13 countries cited by the media watchdog group.

The 13 countries accounted for 222 of the 318 deaths in the last 10 years, CPJ said, with many of the cases linked to war and civil unrest.

The Committee to Protect Journalists said the countries on its list were home to the majority of journalist killings over the past 10 years.

Somalia was the worst country for the fifth year in a row in a ranking based on deaths as a percentage of each country's population -- 25 unsolved killings in a country of 15 million people.

Syria was second and Iraq third on the list.

The countries 'represent a mix of conflict-ridden regions and more stable countries where criminal groups, politicians, government officials, and other powerful actors resort to violence to silence critical and investigative reporting.'

Other countries making up the 13 worst were South Sudan, Afghanistan, Pakistan, Brazil, Bangladesh, Russia, Nigeria and India.

'In the past decade, armed militant groups such as Al-Shabaab, Boko Haram and the Islamic State group have most often targeted journalists with complete impunity,' the CPJ report said.

'However, criminal groups have become a major threat, killing large numbers of journalists and routinely escaping justice. Mexico, to date this year's deadliest country for journalists, has seen its impunity rating worsen nearly every year since 2008, as criminal cartels waged a campaign of terror against the media.'
description: The murders of at least 30 journalists have gone unsolved in the last 10 years, making Mexico the second most dangerous country for the working media in the last decade.
